title: Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists and hypertension: Is there a rationale?

reference.author: B Pitt
reference.unstructured: Pitt B, Zannad F, Remme WJ, et al.: The effect of spironolactone on morbidity and mortality in patients with severe heart failure. Randomized Aldactone Evaluation Study Investigators. N Engl J Med 1999, 341:709–719.

reference.author: B Pitt
reference.unstructured: Pitt B, Remme W, Zannad F, et al.: Eplerenone, a selective aldosterone blocker, in patients with left ventricular dysfunction after myocardial infarction. Eplerenone Post-Acute Myocardial Infarction Heart Failure Efficacy and Survival Study Investigators. N Engl J Med 2003, 348:1309–1321. Large, randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial of the selective MR antagonist eplerenone added to standard therapy, including ACE-inhibition, in patients with MI complicated by LV dysfunction. The addition of eplerenone resulted in a 15% reduction in all-cause mortality, which confirmed the results of the RALES trial and extended the use of MR antagonists to such patients.

reference.journal-title: Eur J Contracept Reprod Health Care

reference.author: NJ Brown
reference.unstructured: Brown NJ: Eplerenone: cardiovascular protection. Circulation 2003, 107:2512–2518.

reference.author: MH Weinberger
reference.unstructured: Weinberger MH, Roniker B, Krause SL, Weiss RJ: Eplerenone, a selective aldosterone blocker, in mild-to-moderate hypertension. Am J Hypertens 2002, 15:709–716. Double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial of a selective aldosterone receptor antagonist, eplerenone, in hypertensive patients in whom spironolactone was used as a positive control. This study showed that all doses of eplerenone caused a significant reduction in blood pressure compared with placebo. It also demonstrated that the efficacy of eplerenone in blood pressure reduction was approximately 75% that of spironolactone.

reference.author: WB White
reference.unstructured: White WB, Carr AA, Krause S, et al.: Assessment of the novel selective aldosterone blocker eplerenone using ambulatory and clinical blood pressure in patients with systemic hypertension. Am J Cardiol 2003, 92:38–42.

reference.author: ED Burgess
reference.unstructured: Burgess ED, Lacourciere Y, Ruilope-Urioste LM, et al.: Long-term safety and efficacy of the selective aldosterone blocker eplerenone in patients with essential hypertension. Clin Ther 2003, 25:2388–2404. This open-label, uncontrolled trial of up to 14 months duration provided important information on the long-term safety and efficacy of eplerenone in patients with essential hypertension.

reference.author: JM Flack
reference.unstructured: Flack JM, Oparil S, Pratt JH, et al.: Efficacy and tolerability of eplerenone and losartan in hypertensive black and white patients. J Am Coll Cardiol 2003, 41:1148–1155. Black patients have a higher prevalence of volume-dependent hypertension and blood pressure salt-sensitivity. This double-blind, placebo-controlled trial demonstrated that eplerenone was equally effective in white and black subjects, suggesting that the volumemodifying effect of MR blockade is not the only mechanism involved in MR blockade’s role in reducing blood pressure.

reference.author: HR Black
reference.unstructured: Black HR, Kuller LH, O’Rourke MF, et al.: The first report of the Systolic and Pulse Pressure (SYPP) Working Group. J Hypertens 1999, 17(Suppl5):3–14.

reference.author: WB White
reference.unstructured: White WB, Duprez D, St Hillaire R, et al.: Effects of the selective aldosterone blocker eplerenone versus the calcium antagonist amlodipine in systolic hypertension. Hypertension 2003, 41:1021–1026. Clinical trial that demonstrated the similar efficacy of MR blockade with eplerenone to calcium-channel blockade with amlodipine in older patients with isolated systolic hypertension and widened pulse pressure.

reference.author: H Krum
reference.unstructured: Krum H, Nolly H, Workman D, et al.: Efficacy of eplerenone added to renin-angiotensin blockade in hypertensive patients. Hypertension 2002, 40:117–123.

reference.author: B Pitt
reference.unstructured: Pitt B, Reichek N, Willenbrock R, et al.: Effects of eplerenone, enalapril, and eplerenone/enalapril in patients with essential hypertension and left ventricular hypertrophy: the 4E-left ventricular hypertrophy study. Circulation 2003, 108:1831–1838. This randomized, double-blind trial showed that eplerenone was as effective as enalapril in regressing LVH. The combination therapy resulted in a significantly greater benefit than eplerenone alone, suggesting that the cardiovascular benefit of eplerenone is additive with an ACE-inhibition.

reference.author: M Epstein
reference.unstructured: Epstein M, Buckalew V, Martinez F, et al.: Antiproteinuric efficacy of eplerenone, enalapril, and eplerenone/enalapril combination in diabetic hypertensives with microalbuminuria [abstract]. Am J Hypertens 2002, 15:24A. This clinical trial showed that hypertensive patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus had similar reductions in microalbuminuria with eplerenone and enalapril treatments. However, the combination produced a greater reduction in proteinuria than either therapy alone, which suggests that blocking effects of angiotensin II and aldosterone may confer a greater renal protection.

reference.author: M Epstein
reference.unstructured: Epstein M, Wienberger M, Lewin A, et al.: The selective aldosterone blocker eplerenone reduces proteinuria without concominant hyperkalemia. J Amer Soc Nephrol 2003, 14(Abstracts Issue):F-FC026, 6A. The results of this trial suggest that the cardiovascular benefits of MR blockade might be achieved with a lower dose of eplerenone, which is associated with lower incidence of hyperkalemia.

reference.author: NK Hollenberg
reference.unstructured: Hollenberg NK, Williams GH, Anderson R, et al.: Symptoms and the distress they cause: comparison of an aldosterone antagonist and a calcium channel blocking agent in patients with systolic hypertension. Arch Intern Med 2003, 163(13):1543–1548.
